questions.explanationEnglish: Use "I" for the first person singular subject when talking about yourself.

questions.questionText: _____ is my best friend. (talking about a boy)
questions.explanationEnglish: Use "He" when referring to a male person.
Use "We" for the first person plural subject.

questions.questionText: _____ is a beautiful city. (talking about Paris)
questions.explanationEnglish: Use "It" for things, places, animals, and ideas.
Use "They" for plural subjects (more than one person or thing).
Use "am" with the subject "I".
Use "is" with he/she/it.
Use "are" with you/we/they.
Use "is" with singular nouns.
Use "are" with "we".
Use "an" before words starting with a vowel sound.
Use "a" before words starting with a consonant sound.
Use "the" for unique things (there is only one sun).
Use "an" before "umbrella" because it starts with a vowel sound.

questions.questionText: This is _____ best restaurant in town.
questions.explanationEnglish: Use "the" with superlatives (best, worst, most, etc.).
Present continuous: am/is/are + verb-ing. Use "am" with "I".
Use "is" with he/she/it in present continuous.

questions.questionText: They _____ playing soccer in the park.
questions.explanationEnglish: Use "are" with they/we/you in present continuous.
Use "are" with "you" in present continuous questions.
Use "is" with singular subjects like "the baby".
Use "What" to ask about things or information.
Use "Where" to ask about places.
Use "When" to ask about time.
Use "Who" to ask about people.
Use "Why" to ask about reasons.
Use "How" to ask about manner or method.
Use "on" for surfaces.
Use "in" for enclosed spaces.

questions.questionText: I will meet you _____ the bus stop.
questions.explanationEnglish: Use "at" for specific points or locations.
Use "under" for something below.
Use "on" for things attached to surfaces like walls.
Add "-ed" to regular verbs for past simple.
Add "-ed" to regular verbs for past simple.
Add "-ed" to regular verbs for past simple.
Add "-ed" to regular verbs for past simple.
Add "-ed" to regular verbs for past simple.

questions.questionText: I _____ to New York last summer.
questions.explanationEnglish: Go → went (irregular past tense).
Make → made (irregular past tense).
Know → knew (irregular past tense).

questions.questionText: He _____ a new car last month.
questions.explanationEnglish: Buy → bought (irregular past tense).
Eat → ate (irregular past tense).

questions.questionText: I _____ a strange noise last night.
questions.explanationEnglish: Hear → heard (irregular past tense).

questions.questionText: This book is _____ than that one.
questions.explanationEnglish: Use "more + adjective" for long adjectives in comparatives.
Add "-er" to short adjectives. Double the consonant for CVC words.
Add "-er" to short adjectives for comparatives.

questions.questionText: This exam was _____ than the last one.
questions.explanationEnglish: Change "y" to "i" and add "-er" for adjectives ending in "y".
Good → better (irregular comparative).
Use "Can" to ask for help or make requests.
Use "can" to express ability. No "s" for third person.

questions.questionText: When I was young, I _____ run very fast.
questions.explanationEnglish: Use "could" for past ability.
Use "Could" for polite requests.

questions.questionText: I _____ swim when I was five.
questions.explanationEnglish: Use "couldn't" for past inability.
Present perfect: have/has + past participle. Use for life experiences.
Use "has" with he/she/it. "Already" goes between have/has and past participle.

questions.questionText: They _____ lived here for ten years.
questions.explanationEnglish: Use "have" with they/we/you/I. Use "for" with periods of time.
Use "Have + subject + ever + past participle" for experience questions.
"Just" indicates recent completion. Use present perfect.

questions.questionText: If it _____, we will stay home.
questions.explanationEnglish: First conditional: If + present simple, will + base verb.

questions.questionText: If you study hard, you _____ the exam.
questions.explanationEnglish: Use "will + base verb" in the result clause.

questions.questionText: She _____ angry if you are late.
questions.explanationEnglish: Use "will be" for future result in first conditional.

questions.questionText: If I _____ time, I will call you.
questions.explanationEnglish: Use present simple after "if" in first conditional.

questions.questionText: We _____ go to the beach if the weather is nice.
questions.explanationEnglish: Use "will" for the result clause in first conditional.

questions.questionText: If I _____ rich, I would travel the world.
questions.explanationEnglish: Second conditional: If + past simple, would + base verb. Use "were" for all subjects.

questions.questionText: If she _____ here, she would help us.
questions.explanationEnglish: Use "were" (not "was") in formal second conditional.

questions.questionText: I _____ buy a house if I had more money.
questions.explanationEnglish: Use "would + base verb" in the result clause.

questions.questionText: If they _____ harder, they would succeed.
questions.explanationEnglish: Use past simple after "if" in second conditional.

questions.questionText: What _____ you do if you won the lottery?
questions.explanationEnglish: Use "would" in questions about hypothetical situations.
Passive voice: be + past participle. Use "was" for past singular.
Use "is" for present passive with singular subjects.
Use "are" for present passive with plural subjects.
Use "was" for past passive with singular subjects.
Use "are" for present passive with plural subjects.

questions.questionText: By the time I arrived, she _____ already left.
questions.explanationEnglish: Past perfect: had + past participle. For actions before another past action.

questions.questionText: I _____ never seen such a beautiful sunset before that day.
questions.explanationEnglish: Use past perfect for experiences before a specific past time.

questions.questionText: They _____ finished dinner when we called.
questions.explanationEnglish: Past perfect shows the earlier of two past events.

questions.questionText: She realized she _____ forgotten her keys.
questions.explanationEnglish: The forgetting happened before the realizing.

questions.questionText: If I _____ known, I would have helped.
questions.explanationEnglish: Third conditional uses past perfect in the if-clause.

questions.questionText: If I had studied harder, I _____ passed the exam.
questions.explanationEnglish: Third conditional: If + past perfect, would have + past participle.

questions.questionText: She _____ come if you had invited her.
questions.explanationEnglish: Use "would have + past participle" for unreal past results.

questions.questionText: If they _____ arrived earlier, they would have met him.
questions.explanationEnglish: Use past perfect after "if" in third conditional.

questions.questionText: I _____ told you if I had known.
questions.explanationEnglish: Third conditional expresses regret about past situations.

questions.questionText: If we _____ taken a taxi, we would have arrived on time.
questions.explanationEnglish: Past perfect in the condition clause of third conditional.
In reported speech, present tense becomes past tense.

questions.questionText: He told me he _____ call me later.
questions.explanationEnglish: In reported speech, "will" becomes "would".

questions.questionText: They said they _____ been waiting for an hour.
questions.explanationEnglish: Present perfect becomes past perfect in reported speech.
In reported questions, use statement word order and past tense.

questions.questionText: He asked if I _____ help him.
questions.explanationEnglish: "Can" becomes "could" in reported speech.

questions.questionText: Not only _____ she intelligent, but she is also hardworking.
questions.explanationEnglish: Inversion after "Not only": auxiliary + subject + main verb.
Inversion after negative adverbs like "rarely".

questions.questionText: Had I known about the meeting, I _____ attended.
questions.explanationEnglish: Inverted conditional: Had + subject replaces If + subject + had.

questions.questionText: It was John _____ broke the window.
questions.explanationEnglish: Cleft sentence: It + be + focus + who/that + rest of sentence.
Pseudo-cleft sentence: What + clause + be + focus.

questions.questionText: I suggest that he _____ more careful.
questions.explanationEnglish: Subjunctive mood: base form after verbs like suggest, recommend, insist.

questions.questionText: It is essential that she _____ on time.
questions.explanationEnglish: Use base form (no -s) in subjunctive after "It is essential that".

questions.questionText: The doctor recommended that he _____ smoking.
questions.explanationEnglish: Subjunctive uses base form regardless of subject.

questions.questionText: If I _____ you, I would accept the offer.
questions.explanationEnglish: Use "were" (subjunctive) for hypothetical situations with all subjects.

questions.questionText: I wish I _____ speak French fluently.
questions.explanationEnglish: Use past forms after "wish" for present wishes.

questions.questionText: The project is still up in the _____.
questions.explanationEnglish: "Up in the air" means uncertain or undecided.

questions.questionText: She has a chip on her _____.
questions.explanationEnglish: "Chip on one's shoulder" means holding a grudge or being easily offended.
"Beat around the bush" means to avoid the main topic.
"Barking up the wrong tree" means pursuing a mistaken course.
"The last straw" is the final problem that makes a situation unbearable.

questions.questionText: I _____ have done it, but I chose not to.
questions.explanationEnglish: "Could have" expresses past ability/possibility that wasn't used.
"Should have" expresses expectation about the past.
"Ought not to have" is more formal than "shouldn't have".

questions.questionText: The data _____ that the hypothesis is correct.
questions.explanationEnglish: "Data" can be treated as plural (formal) or singular (informal).

questions.questionText: Neither the students nor the teacher _____ aware of the change.
questions.explanationEnglish: With "neither...nor", the verb agrees with the nearest subject.

feedbackMessages.messageEnglish: Perfect! You're really getting the hang of this!
feedbackMessages.messageGerman: Perfekt! Du bekommst das wirklich gut hin!

feedbackMessages.messageEnglish: Great job! Your English is improving!
feedbackMessages.messageGerman: Tolle Arbeit! Dein Englisch verbessert sich!
feedbackMessages.messageChinese: 做得好！你的英语在进步！

feedbackMessages.messageEnglish: Brilliant! Keep up the excellent work!
Not quite, but don't give up! Try again.
feedbackMessages.messageArabic: ليس تماماً، لكن لا تستسلم! حاول مرة أخرى.
feedbackMessages.messageFrench: Pas tout à fait, mais n'abandonne pas! Réessaie.
feedbackMessages.messageSpanish: No del todo, ¡pero no te rindas! Inténtalo de nuevo.
feedbackMessages.messageGerman: Nicht ganz, aber gib nicht auf! Versuch es nochmal.
feedbackMessages.messageChinese: 不太对，但别放弃！再试一次。

feedbackMessages.messageEnglish: Almost there! Let's review this together.
feedbackMessages.messageGerman: Fast! Lass uns das zusammen durchgehen.
feedbackMessages.messageChinese: 差一点！让我们一起复习。

feedbackMessages.messageEnglish: Good try! The correct answer is different.
feedbackMessages.messageFrench: Bon essai! La bonne réponse est différente.
feedbackMessages.messageSpanish: ¡Buen intento! La respuesta correcta es diferente.
feedbackMessages.messageGerman: Guter Versuch! Die richtige Antwort ist anders.
feedbackMessages.messageChinese: 不错的尝试！正确答案不同。

feedbackMessages.messageEnglish: That's not it, but you're learning!
feedbackMessages.messageFrench: Ce n'est pas ça, mais tu apprends!
feedbackMessages.messageGerman: Das ist es nicht, aber du lernst!

feedbackMessages.messageEnglish: Oops! Let me explain the correct answer.
feedbackMessages.messageFrench: Oups! Laisse-moi expliquer la bonne réponse.
feedbackMessages.messageGerman: Hoppla! Lass mich die richtige Antwort erklären.
feedbackMessages.messageChinese: 哎呀！让我解释正确答案。

lessons.title: Saying Hello
lessons.targetText: Hello! My name is... Nice to meet you!
lessons.culturalNote: Americans often use informal greetings like "Hey" with friends.
lessons.practiceDialogue: A: Hello! My name is Sarah. B: Hi Sarah! Nice to meet you. I'm Mike.

lessons.title: Asking How Someone Is
lessons.targetText: How are you? I'm fine, thank you. And you?
lessons.culturalNote: "How are you?" is often a greeting, not a real question.
lessons.practiceDialogue: A: How are you doing? B: I'm doing great, thanks! How about you?

lessons.title: Saying Goodbye
lessons.targetText: Goodbye! See you later! Take care!
lessons.culturalNote: Americans often say "See ya!" as an informal goodbye.
lessons.practiceDialogue: A: I have to go now. B: Okay, see you later! Take care!

lessons.title: Morning Activities
lessons.targetText: I wake up at 7 AM. I brush my teeth and eat breakfast.
lessons.culturalNote: Many Americans drink coffee with breakfast.
lessons.practiceDialogue: A: What time do you wake up? B: I usually wake up at 7.

lessons.title: Work and School
lessons.targetText: I go to work at 9 AM. I work until 5 PM.
lessons.culturalNote: The typical American workday is 9 to 5.
lessons.practiceDialogue: A: Where do you work? B: I work at a bank downtown.

lessons.title: At the Store
lessons.targetText: How much does this cost? Can I pay by card?
lessons.culturalNote: Credit cards are widely accepted in the US.
lessons.practiceDialogue: A: How much is this shirt? B: It's $25. A: I'll take it.

lessons.title: Email Writing
lessons.targetText: Dear Mr. Smith, I am writing to inquire about...
lessons.culturalNote: American business emails are often more direct than in other cultures.
lessons.practiceDialogue: Writing a professional email requesting information.

lessons.title: Expressing Opinions
lessons.targetText: In my opinion... I believe that... On the other hand...
lessons.culturalNote: Americans value direct but respectful disagreement.
lessons.practiceDialogue: Discussing pros and cons of a topic.

lessons.title: Structuring Arguments
lessons.targetText: The evidence suggests... This leads us to conclude...
lessons.culturalNote: American academic style values clarity and evidence.

lessons.title: Idioms & Cultural References
lessons.targetText: It's not rocket science. Let's touch base later.
lessons.culturalNote: Understanding cultural references is key to native-like fluency.
